The Bank of England on Thursday surprised the financial markets and delighted British businesses with a 0.25 percentage point cut in its main interest rate to 5 per cent. Interest rates have not been lower since early 1964.
But the mood inspired by the cut was marred by the European Central Bank's refusal to cut rates, and by concern at the Bank of England's growing pessimism about the global outlook.
Forecasters had expected the Bank's monetary policy committee to leave rates unchanged because of fears more cuts would fuel consumer demand and threaten higher inflation.
But the MPC said the unexpected severity of the global slowdown meant rates had to fall to keep inflation on track to hit its 2.5 per cent target in two years.
"Monetary policy needs to balance the weaker external environment by sustaining domestic demand growth," it said. The MPC believes a two-speed economy of weak internationally traded sectors and strong consumer demand is better than an economy in recession.
Since last month's MPC meeting, which voted eight to one to leave rates unchanged, there have been few signs domestic demand is cooling. Retail sales, household borrowing and house prices have generally been strong.
But manufacturing output, especially in the technology sector, has continued to fall sharply.
In the second quarter the US economy slowed to its lowest growth rate in eight years and the German economy is believed to have contracted.
The timing of Thursday's cut may have been prompted by the Bank's latest quarterly round of economic forecasting, to be published next week.
David Walton of Goldman Sachs said: "They have updated their forecasts and, although inflation has been disappointing recently, the MPC are confident that it will remain on target further out."
Some City analysts said the Bank was building up a potential inflationary threat for the future. Michael Saunders of Schroder Salomon Smith Barney said: "This won't do anything for the global outlook but . . . it will give the housing market a push."
But other economists supported the move. Martin Weale of the National Institute of Economic and Social Research said: "The world's three largest economies - the US Japan and Germany - are all very weak, and the Bank of England was right not to be distracted by the fact that some consumption indicators are buoyant."
Hopes that the international economy might soon begin to pick up were dented when, an hour after the MPC's announcement, the European Central Bank said its governing council had decided against cutting interest rates.
Ian Fletcher of the British Chambers of Commerce said: "In terms of supporting British manufacturing, we need a more concerted effort to cut rates and revive growth, and we don't think the ECB is playing ball."
